articles.headline: Boehner Doubts Immigration Bill Will Pass in 2014
articles.snippet: Speaker John A. Boehner’s pronouncement significantly narrowed the window for success on the issue this year and left it to President Obama to win the trust of Republicans.
articles.abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner’s pronouncement significantly narrowed the window for success on the issue this year and left it to President Obama to win the trust of Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The yearlong effort to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws, which had the support of President Obama, Republican leaders and much of American business and labor, was seriously imperiled on Thursday when Speaker John A. Boehner conceded that it was unlikely he could pass a bill.

articles.headline: Russia Claims U.S. Is Meddling Over Ukraine
articles.snippet: Meanwhile, the Obama administration blamed Moscow for spreading an intercepted private conversation between two American diplomats.
articles.abstract: Meanwhile, the Obama administration blamed Moscow for spreading an intercepted private conversation between two American diplomats.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The tense Russian-American jockeying over the fate of Ukraine escalated on Thursday as a Kremlin official accused Washington of “crudely interfering” in the former Soviet republic, while the Obama administration blamed Moscow for spreading an intercepted private conversation between two American diplomats.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Ex-SAC Trader Convicted of Securities Fraud
articles.snippet: With the conviction of Mr. Martoma, the nearly decade-long investigation of Steven Cohen and his hedge fund may have seen its last criminal prosecution.
articles.abstract: With the conviction of Mr. Martoma, the nearly decade-long investigation of Steven Cohen and his hedge fund may have seen its last criminal prosecution.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mathew Martoma had been on his way to being another American success story. Today, he is the eighth person who once worked for the hedge fund titan Steven A. Cohen to be convicted of insider trading.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Ideas to Make Retirement Possible
articles.snippet: One proposal would bring back pensions while a plan by the Obama administration would give younger people a break on market risk.
articles.abstract: One proposal would bring back pensions while a plan by the Obama administration would give younger people a break on market risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who killed pensions? Can they be resurrected?

articles.headline: Legal Troubles Barely Subdue a Bitcoin Evangelist’s Sermons
articles.snippet: Charles Shrem, the Bitcoin enthusiast, says he hopes one day to return to the world of the virtual currency, maybe as its chief aficianado.
articles.abstract: Charles Shrem, the Bitcoin enthusiast, says he hopes one day to return to the world of the virtual currency, maybe as its chief aficianado.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few weeks before his arrest at Kennedy Airport, Charles Shrem was standing behind the Manhattan bar he invested in with some of his Bitcoin fortune, buzzing about his big plans for the virtual currency and himself.

articles.headline: Skating Close to the Edge, Again, on the Debt Ceiling
articles.snippet: There’s less congressional appetite for brinkmanship this time, but the government has only a few weeks’ worth of cash left.
articles.abstract: There’s less congressional appetite for brinkmanship this time, but the government has only a few weeks’ worth of cash left.

articles.headline: Long-Haul Expansion by a Norwegian Carrier Upsets U.S. Airlines
articles.snippet: American labor groups, airlines and pilots say Norwegian Air Shuttle’s expansion plans take unfair advantage of a U.S.-Europe open-skies agreement.
articles.abstract: American labor groups, airlines and pilots say Norwegian Air Shuttle’s expansion plans take unfair advantage of a U.S.-Europe open-skies agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Flying doesn’t come cheaply these days, particularly on long-haul flights across the Atlantic.

articles.headline: Past Fictions, a Lack of Trust and No Deal in SAC Case
articles.snippet: Mathew Martoma seemed to be able to cut a deal with prosecutors, but his handling of a years-old episode involving fabrication of documents casts doubt on his trustworthiness, James B. Stewart writes in the Common Sense column.
articles.abstract: Mathew Martoma seemed to be able to cut a deal with prosecutors, but his handling of a years-old episode involving fabrication of documents casts doubt on his trustworthiness, James B. Stewart writes in the Common Sense column.
articles.lead_paragraph: The guilty verdict on Thursday against the former SAC trader Mathew Martoma only deepens a mystery about the case: Given the overwhelming evidence against him, why did he fight the charges of insider trading, risking a lengthy prison term, rather than make a deal with the government to cooperate in return for leniency?

articles.headline: Payroll Data Shows a Lag in Wages, Not Just Hiring
articles.snippet: Payrolls in the United States grew by 113,000 in January, a weaker-than-expected increase that experts said may signal a loss of momentum in the economy. The unemployment rate dipped to 6.6 percent.
articles.abstract: Payrolls in the United States grew by 113,000 in January, a weaker-than-expected increase that experts said may signal a loss of momentum in the economy. The unemployment rate dipped to 6.6 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the more than 10 million Americans who are out of work, finding a job is hard. For the 145 million or so who are employed, getting a raise is even harder.
